metadata.title: Brain Tumor Prediction with Machine Learning
metadata.description: This review aims to systematically analyze ML models from four aspects: The investigation is based on the nurture of the ML technique, estimation precision, model evolution, and estimation setting. The systematic literature review of empirical studies focused on the published articles on ML models of the last decades. From the above sources, fifty-one primary studies concerning the objective of this research were identified on analyzing these studies; five ML techniques have been using it in the classification and prediction of brain tumors. the accuracies achieved by the estimated ML models can be consistories satisfactory, as they either match or surpass those of non-3fL models. The phenomenon of using improved machine learning models to classify and predict brain tumors him been the subject of numerous studies. Accenting to the mutters of the corresponding words, the genetic algorithm achieve‹t the highest level of prediction accuracy more than 10 among null the models that were tried. However, because of their complexity, these 3fL models have not yet been adopted by the industry and thus need more development.
keywords: Brain Turner; Machine Learning; Prediction, Medical Imaging; Classification, Neurul Networks; Computer Aided Diagnosis Early Detection
references: 1.	American Cancer Society. (2021). Cancer facts & figures 2021.
2.	Chen, J., et al. (2020). Reading the fine print of machine learning for healthcare. IEEE Access.
3.	Clark, K., et al. (2013). The Cancer Imaging Archive (TCIA): The need to run and sustain a public information archive. Journal of Digital Imaging.

4.	Havaei, M., et al. (2017). Using advances in computer-assisted interventions and medical imaging, Havaei and colleagues investigated the potential of deep learning to enhance prostate cancer detection.
5.	Jiang, R., et al. (2020). Machine learning for brain tumour early detection. Frontiers in Neuroscience.
6.	Khosravi, P., et al. (2019). Personalized medicine in cancer: Opportunities and challenges. Journal of Personalized Medicine.
7.	Marcus, D. S., et al. (2007). OASIS: The Open Access Series of Imaging Studies. NeuroImage.
8.	Menze, B. H., et al. (2015). Multimodal brain tumor image segmentation: The BRATS challenge. IEEE Periodicals on Medical Imaging.
9.	Müller, H. W., et al. (2019). Application of PET scan in therapy of brain tumors. Current Treatment Options in Oncology.
10.	Morris, E. R., et al. (2018). Machine learning in neurology: A paper close to clinical practice. Journal of Neurology.

journal.title: Journal of Advancement in Parallel Computing

metadata.title: Role of Marine Natural Products in Combating SARS-CoV-2 and COVID-19
metadata.description: From the inception of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic has plague-ridden several millions of human beings across the world in a short time interval and force the world to experience extraordinary economic and life loss. Consequently, it is compulsory to find operational cures against severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus-2 (SARS-CoV-2), because it is the biological cause of COVID-19. Synthetic medicines, such as hydroxychloroquine, have acquired large attention. Though, the effectiveness of this drug is still under examination, and moreover, certain severe consequences are a source of distress. This underlines the urgency for treatment alternatives, which can be in cooperation with efficiency and safety. Until now, there are no specifically recognized drugs to fight this virus and the procedure for new drug development is prolonged. Most encouraging candidates, which emerged as prospective frontrunners, were abandoned later while still in the phase of clinical examinations. With no convinced therapeutics in the prospect, natural products are in wide use randomly as anti-viral remedy and immune promoters. For centuries it has been well-known that most marine natural products have effective anti-viral properties with SARS-CoV-2. It has been exposed that natural products show inhibitory activities on Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus (MERS-CoV) and SARS-CoV infections.
keywords: Severe acute respiratory syndrome, Middle east respiratory syndrome coronavirus, Coronavirus disease, Clinical examination, Anti-viral properties.

metadata.description: Figure 8 Geographic distribution of Ichnotropis within Angolan territory, on a greyscale elevation map (Fick and Hijmans 2017). Different colors depict records of different species within Ichnotropis; see the inset for color explanations. Circles represent historical records, triangles denote newly collected material, and start denotes type localities.

metadata.title: Figure 6 from: Benito M, Conradie W, Vaz Pinto P, Lobón-Rovira J (2025) A needle in a haystack: Rediscovery and revised description of Ichnotropis microlepidota Marx, 1956, from the central highlands of Angola. metadata.description: Figure 6 Detailed views in A. Dorsal; B. Lateral; C. Ventral; D. Frontal; E. Posterior of skull, and F. Medial; G. Ventral; H. Dorsal; I. Lateral view of the right jaw of Ichnotropis microlepidota (MHNCUP-REP0983). Abbreviations: aSo, anterior supraocular; Bc, braincase; Co, coronoid; CB, compound bone; D, dentary; EcP, ectopterygoid; EP, epipterygoid; F, frontal; J, jugal; Lc, lacrimal; M, maxilla; mSo, middle supraocupar; N, nasal; Ot, otostape; P, parietal; PF, prefrontal; Pl, palatine; PM, premaxilla; PO, postorbital; pSo, posterior supraocular; Pt, pretygoid; Q, quadrate; SM, septomaxilla; SO, supraorbital; Sp, splenial; Sq, squamosal; SR, sclerotic ring; ST, supratemporal; V, vomer. Scale bars represent 10 mm.

metadata.title: Figure 5 from: Benito M, Conradie W, Vaz Pinto P, Lobón-Rovira J (2025) A needle in a haystack: Rediscovery and revised description of Ichnotropis microlepidota Marx, 1956, from the central highlands of Angola. metadata.description: Figure 5 Specimen of Ichnotropis microlepidota (MHNCUP-REP0983) from Mount Moco, Huambo Province, Angola. (A, B) Dorsal and ventral view of the preserved specimen. Details of the head of the preserved specimen in (C) dorsal, (D) lateral, and (E) ventral view. (F) Detail of pelvic region and hind limbs. Scale bars represent 15 mm. In life pictures of the full body (G) and detail of the head (H). Photos by Max Benito and Pedro Vaz Pinto.

metadata.description: Figure 4 Comparative visualization of the skulls of Ichnotropis microlepidota (MHNCUP-REP0983) and I. bivittata (RMCA 14641; MCZ-R39726) (from left to right). Detail of the skull in A. Dorsal; B. Lateral, and C. Ventral views; and lower jaws in D. Dorsal; E. Lateral; F. Ventral, and G. Medial views. For the color palette, see Suppl. material 1: table S3. Scale bars: 10 mm.

metadata.title: Figure 3 from: Benito M, Conradie W, Vaz Pinto P, Lobón-Rovira J (2025) A needle in a haystack: Rediscovery and revised description of Ichnotropis microlepidota Marx, 1956, from the central highlands of Angola. Zoosystematics and Evolution 101(2): 887-906. https://doi.org/10.3897/zse.101.136290
metadata.description: Figure 3 Boxplot (top whisker – maximum value; lower whisker – minimum value; bold horizontal line – median; box – 1st and 3rd quartile) displaying meristic measurements of Ichnotropis species. Different colors depict records of different species within Ichnotropis; see inset for color explanations. Significative values between I. microlepidota and other Ichnotropis species are highlighted under the graphics. For all ANOVA results see Suppl. material 1: table S6. For abbreviations see the Materials and Methods section.

metadata.title: Figure 2 from: Benito M, Conradie W, Vaz Pinto P, Lobón-Rovira J (2025) A needle in a haystack: Rediscovery and revised description of Ichnotropis microlepidota Marx, 1956, from the central highlands of Angola. metadata.description: Figure 2 A. PCA plot of the first principal component (PC1) versus the second principal component (PC2) on Dataset 1 including all the morphological variables; B. PCA plot of the first principal component (PC1) versus the second principal component (PC2) of Dataset 1, excluding the three main morphological variables of the head (i.e., HL, HW, HH). Species are represented by different color and symbol included in the legend. For abbreviations see the Materials and Methods section. For loadings of all axes and explained variance, see Suppl. material 1: tables S4, S5.
